game.desc: Video games and things that aspired to be video games.

gameDesign.desc: Things related to game design, such as game design documents or level design sketches.

art.desc: 2D Art, either created physically or digitally.

misc.desc: Projects that don't fit neatly into any other category.

firstPerson.desc: Displayed from a first-person camera perspective.

thirdPerson.desc: Displayed from a third-person camera perspective.

topDown.desc: Displayed from a top-down camera perspective.

sideScroller.desc: Displayed from a side-view camera perspective.

isometric.desc: Displayed from a isometric projection based camera perspective.

action.desc: Emphasizes physical challenges, such as hand-eye coordination & reaction time.

strategy.desc: Emphasizes decision-making skills and complex strategical thinking.

turnBased.desc: Gameplay takes place within distinct turns.

puzzle.desc: Is either directly a puzzle, or a game with an emphasis on solving puzzles.

shooter.desc: A subgenre of action games, defined by the use of projectile weaponry, generally being used to defeat enemies.

rogueLike.desc: A subgenre of role-playing games, primarily defined by procedurally generated environments and permanent death of the player character.

physicalSketch.desc: A sketch drawn using physical mediums.

digitalSketch.desc: A sketch drawn using digital software.

pixelArt.desc: Digital art with importance placed on individual pixels.

modelWeapon.desc: A 3D model depicting some form of weaponry.

3dEnvironment.desc: A designed environment created within a 3D space.

html.desc: (HyperText Markup Language) The standard markup language for documents displayed in a web browser.

css.desc: (Cascading Style Sheets) A style sheet language for describing the presentation of a markup document.

javaScript.desc: An object-oriented programming language used to create interactive webpage behavior.

cSharp.desc: A general-purpose high-level programming language supporting multiple paradigms.

unity.desc: A cross-platform game engine developed by Unity Technologies.

blender.desc: A free & open-source 3D computer graphics software used to create 3D models.

krita.desc: A free & open-source raster graphics (image) editor.

touchDesigner.desc: An interactive design application that allows users to create real-time interactive content developed by Derivative.

photoshop.desc: A raster graphics (image) editor developed by Adobe Inc.

illustrator.desc: A vector graphics editor developed by Adobe Inc.

afterEffects.desc: A visual effects, motion graphics, & video editing software developed by Adobe Inc.

atom.desc: Was a free & open-source source-code editor made by GitHub. (No longer under development.)

vsCode.desc: (Visual Studio Code) A source-code editor made by Microsoft.

games.title: Untitled Bow Game
games.desc_brief: A first-person puzzle game, centered around using a bow and various arrows with special effects, developed with Unity.
games.desc_detailed:
Overview

This game project was created as a semester long project for my Game Development Class. The original concept I had for this was to be a first-person metroidvania centered around the use of a bow for both combat and puzzle solving.

There was a lot of other mechanics I had thought of, but didn't have the time to implement, and the majority of my time and effort was spent on programming, which unfortunately led to insufficient time to work on the level design. However, regardless of the rough state it may currently be in, this project was the first more complex 3D game project I developed with Unity (and in general), and I learned a lot from working on it.

Original Design Document Excerpt

Overview

  • A 3D first-person Metroidvania with Combat, but a primary focus on puzzles.
  • The game will focus around the use of a bow and arrow(s) for both combat and puzzle solving.
  • The arrows shot by the bow will embed themselves into the environment and may provide various effects, however, there is a limit on how many of these arrows may exist at once.
  • Shooting an arrow when at max arrow count will despawn the oldest arrow, or the player may manually despawn arrows.
  • Hitting an enemy will not count towards the arrow limit.
  • The max arrow limit will be raised throughout the game.
  • New arrow types will be introduced throughout the game.

Core Mechanics

  • Jumping / Platforming
  • Shooting Bow and Arrows
  • Picking Up And Dropping Objects

Player Actions

  • Walk / Run
  • Jump / Double Jump
  • Shoot Bow and Arrow
  • Change Arrow Type
  • Activate Buttons and Levers
  • Pick Up, Drop, and Throw Objects

Arrow Type Examples

  • Basic Arrow:
    • Sticks into objects & can activate buttons / plates.
    • Deals damage to enemies. (As do all other arrows.)
  • Tether Arrow:
    • When embedded into certain objects, they can be pulled towards the player.
    • Two tether arrows can be shot consecutively to form a connection between two objects.
  • Grapple Arrow:
    • Upgraded tether arrow, when embedded into a valid object, the player can be pulled towards it.
  • Ghost Arrow:
    • When embedded into a valid object, the object becomes intangible, allowing objects to travel through it.

games.title: JavaScript 2.5D Raycasting Engine

links.desc: Link to the GitHub hosted web page where you can play this game.
Link to the GitHub Repository for this game.

games.desc_brief: A simple 2.5D raycasting engine/game, similar to Wolfenstein 3D, developed with JavaScript.
games.desc_detailed:
Overview

A simple 2.5D raycasting engine/game programmed in JavaScript, drawing onto a HTML canvas, and using HTML & CSS for most of the UI. This game started as a final project for my Creative Coding 2 class, but I continued working on it for a few months afterwards.
This was by far the most complex project I had developed at the time, it was something I really enjoyed working on, and I learned a lot about game development and programming from making it.

2.5D Raycasting Engine

In case you're not aware, a 2.5D raycasting engine is a game engine that technically operates in 2D space, but is rendered to appear 3D. This is done by casting 'rays' from the player's position in a cone, and detecting at what distance it hits a wall, which determines the height that portion of the wall is rendered at. This type of rendering was common in the early days of "3D" P.C. video games, with some notable examples being Wolfenstein 3D, Doom, and Duke Nukem 3D. If you want a more in depth description of raycasting, feel free to look through the credited websites listed below.

img_thumbnail.desc: Screenshot depicting the player being shot at by an enemy.

slideshowSlides.desc: Screenshot depicting the player shooting enemies.
Screenshot depicting the player interacting with a lever, which triggers a change in the level's map.
Screenshot depicting an enemy shortly after it was killed.
Screenshot depicting the minimap (which shows the entire level layout).
Screenshot showing the game's simple main menu.
Screenshot showing the game's general options menu.
Screenshot showing the game's keybinds menu.

credits.displayName: "Make 3D Javascript Raycasting Engine" by Maksim Ivanov.
credits.desc: This video tutorial served as the basis for this project, but, it was to simple for all the features I wanted, and so I had to rely on other tutorials as well.

credits.displayName: "Creating Pseudo 3D Games With HTML 5 Canvas and Raycasting" by Jacob Seidelin.
credits.desc: This fairly old tutorial (2008) uses a very different rendering method from my project, but helped serve as the foundation for expanding upon the game's rendering engine thanks to providing many specific math formulas necessary for rendering.

credits.displayName: "Ray-Casting Tutorial For Game Development And Other Purposes" by F. Permadi.
credits.desc: This tutorial helped me in expanding upon the functionality of the game by explaining several more complex concepts behind raycasting engines.

credits.displayName: "Lode's Computer Graphics Tutorial - Raycasting" by Lode Vandevenne.
credits.desc: This tutorial helped to explain how much of the math behind raycast rendering worked.

credits.displayName: "Javascript State Machine" by 'jakesgordon' on GitHub.
credits.desc: A library for implementing finite state machines in JavaScript. Used to create the simple enemy A.I.

games.title: Project Undead Strategy
games.desc_brief: A simple rogue-like with turn-based grid combat, developed with Unity.
games.desc_detailed:
Overview

A simple rogue-like with turn-based grid combat developed with Unity. Originally made as a semester long project for my Game Engines class. This project is fairly bare-bones, and I wasn't able to get nearly as much done as I had originally hoped, as I simply ran out of time. Because this was the first bigger project I developed in Unity, I had to do a lot of learning as I went, and ended up needing to rework large portions of it, so while it's not my best work, I'm still proud of all the work I put into it and how much I learned from making it.

Original Design Document Excerpt

A Brief Description

Rogue-like with turn-based strategy grid combat similar to Advance Wars. Features a leveling system, equipment system, and uses a map system similar to Slay the Spire. The player plays the role of a necromancer who can summon undead units to fight their enemies.

Combat

Combat is turn-based and takes place upon a square grid. The player and A.I. will take turns where they may command every unit they have.

Commander Unit

The commander unit is a necromancer which represents the player tends to be much stronger than other units and as effective against all unit types. However, the commander is the only unit whose health doesn’t reset after battle, and the commander’s death results in a game over.

Minion Units

Other than the commander there are three other unit types: melee, ranged, and aerial. The unit types mostly act as a simple rock, paper, scissors dynamic within the prototype, but would ideally be expanded upon with greater complexity through additional types and differing levels of effectiveness against each other.

Unit Stats

  • Movement Speed: Determines how far the unit may travel within a single turn.
  • Attack Range: Determines how close/far a target must be for the unit to attack it.
  • Accuracy: Determines chance to hit. (Most units have 100% accuracy, but this may be altered by effects or something.)
  • Health: Decreases when attacked, the unit will die if it reaches zero, and modifies how much damage the unit deals.
  • Attack: Determines how much base damage is dealt when the unit attacks. (Actual damage is affected by things like type effectiveness.)

Unit Types

  • Melee: Effective against range, but cannot hit aerial units (subject to change?).
  • Ranged: Effective against aerial units, but they’re slower and cannot attack units within 1 (2?) cell away from them.
  • Aerial: Effective against melee and they’re faster, but {more expensive? rarer? low accuracy?}.

Terrain

  • Various terrain types will have different defense values which decrease how much damage units on them will take from attacks.
  • Some terrain will decrease how far a unit may travel within one turn. Though some units (such as aerial) may not be affected by some of these speed penalties.

Unit Limitations

  • The commander unit is a necromancer, and as such can revive and heal/repair their units after every battle. And while the player isn’t limited by the number of units they may add to their army, they are limited to how many can be used within battle. This is because summoning a unit requires a specific amount of a limited resource (which is fully recovered after every battle).
  • All units have a rarity tier which may be used to determine if certain perks / equipment affect them. (ex: All basic minions have +4 health.)

Map System

Map Layout

  • A map will consist of a series of connected dots where the player may travel from one dot to another. [FTL: Faster Than Light, Slay the Spire]
  • Each dot on the map will contain either a combat encounter, an event, or a rest point (& possibly a shop if I get that far).
  • Rest points (safe zone? campsite?) are where the player may replenish their commander’s health.

Map Events

  • Most map events that aren’t combat will be presented in the form of a short explanation presented alongside an image, with one or more possible outcomes to choose from.
  • The player may be given the opportunity to combine two or more of their units to create a single stronger unit.

games.title: Untitled Shmup Game
games.desc_brief: A very basic "shoot 'em up" game programmed with JavaScript.
games.desc_detailed:
A very basic "shoot 'em up" game programmed with JavaScript, this version was created as a final project for my Web Technologies class. The original version was created with the use of p5.js, but this version is a rework which removed the use of p5.js functions. (Although, this may be incorrect, as I either forgot to remove the p5.js npm import, or there may still be some use of p5.js that I don't remember.) This game was programmed in JavaScript, and uniquely doesn't use any sprites, instead most visuals being drawn onto the HTML canvas are vertex shapes.

The game is very simple, with no end goal, and simply consists of an endless number of enemies moving across the screen, with a counter of how many the player has defeated. And the player's health is shown in the bottom left corner, which, if lowered to zero by colliding with enemies, will simply freeze the game, but it can be manually restarted via the pause menu.

animation.title: Intro to Animation - Flipbook Animation
animation.desc_brief: A flipbook/frame animation drawn with pencil on notecards.
animation.desc_detailed:
A flipbook/frame animation drawn with pencil on notecards, which was created for my Intro to Animation class. To create the video, the individual notecards were scanned and then edited together with Adobe After Effects.

This animation was unfortunately never fully finished due to simply running out of time. Though I had also underestimated how long the animation's duration would be, as I didn't have a good sense of what the duration between key frames would be, given this was the first time I had ever created a frame animation.

img_thumbnail.desc: Animation thumbnail image.

slideshowSlides.desc: The animation uploaded onto YouTube.
The animation's original story board.

animation.title: Intro to Animation - Stop Motion Animation
animation.desc_brief: A stop motion animation made with photos of clay, wire, cardboard, paper, toothpicks, and other physical mediums.
animation.desc_detailed:
A stop motion animation made with photos of clay, wire, cardboard, paper, toothpicks, and other physical mediums, which was created for my Intro to Animation class. To create the video, the photos were then edited together with Adobe After Effects.

Due to spending far too much time on preparation for the animation (creating the props/set & planning it out), this animation is something that was made in a rather short time frame. And, due to it being rushed, along with having never made a stop motion animation before, I ended up not being able to fulfill my original vision for the animation. Other than the time constraint, another factor that lead to deviating from the storyboard was the clay being heated up under the lighting conditions, thus not being able to hold it's shape as well as I had expected.

Originally I had planned for the ending frame to be near identical to the first frame. The idea being that, despite the art moving around, they would morph into identical copies of other pieces to replace each other. But, despite needing to stray from my original plans, I still feel the animation turned out fairly decent for my first (and only) attempt at stop motion.

img_thumbnail.desc: Animation thumbnail image.

slideshowSlides.desc: The animation uploaded onto YouTube.
The animation's original story board.

animation.title: Animated Robomation Logo
animation.desc_brief: An animated title logo created for a fake game called "Robomation".
animation.desc_detailed:
An animated title logo created for a fake game called "Robomation".
This was created as part of an assignment where I created a fake game trailer, and while the trailer itself isn't something worth showing off, I was fairly happy with this simple little animated title logo.

img_thumbnail.desc: Static image of the animated logo.

slideshowSlides.desc: The animation uploaded onto YouTube.

credits.displayName: "Scandia Line Stencil" designed by Eric Olson, from Process Type Foundry.
credits.desc: The font used in this title logo, which was downloaded through Adobe Fonts.

misc.title: TouchDesigner Audio Visualizer
misc.desc_brief: A customizable audio visualizer created with TouchDesigner.
misc.desc_detailed: A customizable audio visualizer created with TouchDesigner for my Principles of Interactive Art class. This project had originally started as a more simple audio visualizer, and was then expanded upon with multiple visualizer types and color options that can be changed via an overlaid interface.

img_thumbnail.desc: Audio visualizer thumbnail.

slideshowSlides.desc: YouTube video showcasing the audio visualizer.
A screenshot of the displayed video.

credits.displayName: Touch Designer's Official Documentation
"Interim" by Nokae; Uploaded by The Arcadium.
credits.desc: This is the song used in the video showcasing the audio visualizer.
